Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Jamie: “Rough day. Can you talk?” I knew what he needed—someone to listen, to let him vent, maybe even make him laugh. I started typing a reply, but before I could hit send, my work pager shrieked. The ICU’s life-support device was down, flashing urgent red codes. I was the only technician on call. My mind raced: Jamie counted on me to be there, to show I cared, but the hospital needed me to act fast, to keep someone alive. I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the keyboard, heart pounding. I could almost hear Jamie’s voice, tired and hopeful, but the image of the blinking machine and the patient it supported pressed in on me. Both roles demanded my full attention, but I couldn’t split myself in two. The weight of their expectations pressed down, and I felt myself caught in the impossible space between being a good friend and a responsible repairer.
